prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. The key points here are the timeline of events and the communication issues.

First, the author mentions that the friend, G, didn't send a save-the-date and only sent invitations a month before the wedding. That's pretty short notice, especially for international travel. Save-the-dates are typically sent months in advance, so G not doing that is a problem. 

Then, there's the fact that the author and friends had already planned a trip to Australia for two weeks, which starts two days before the wedding. They had invited G to the trip, so she was aware of their plans. The author also notes that G invited 50 people but only expects 20 to attend because of the short notice. This suggests that others might also have scheduling conflicts or couldn't get time off work, which is a common issue with short notice.

The author is being criticized by G for not canceling the trip. But considering that the trip was planned earlier and G didn't give proper notice, it's understandable why the author can't change their plans. Also, the financial aspect is mentioned; they aren't super rich, so canceling would be a huge loss. That adds another layer of difficulty in just dropping the trip.

The friend's reaction seems a bit over the top, expecting others to drop everything for her wedding, especially when she didn't plan properly. The author isn't the only one in the wrong here; G's lack of communication and poor planning contributed to the problem. The author had valid reasons and prior commitments, so they aren't necessarily at fault for sticking to their plans.
